annotation.TEXT: Knight Crush is basically the Metal Blade of this game. It still has a curved trajectory, but it can now be aimed in 6 directions and has refilling ammo when the shot returns to you (similar to Quick Boomerang). It plows through nearly every minor enemy in one hit, and also serves as a soft weakness for nearly every boss in the game as well.

Since he's been promoted to being a secret boss, Knight Man is now obligated to hit like a truck (he can kill you in 4 hits from contact damage alone). He happens to be weak to Rain Flush, but it currently doesn't have enough ammo to put him down. Even then, the fight itself is still manageable...provided you have full health.

Magma Bazooka still retains its highly destructive damage output, though now at the cost of having far less ammo than in the original. It still has its uses, though now it's mainly for set obstacles and mini-boss type enemies (which the charged version can usually take down in one hit)

Aside from the addition of lasers on the ceiling of his room, Magma Man isn't drastically different from his original counterpart (aside from a few extra motions and projectiles he tends to launch out from time to time). During the fight however, I did catch onto something I probably should have mentioned before: the extended invincibility time most Robot Masters get after being hit with a special weapon.

Some of the rooms in this level repurpose the magma beams to mirror Quick Man's lasers to some extent. While they still fire in set intervals, the structure of these sections pretty much guarantees you'll be hit if you stand around. Similar to MM9, you can also freeze the lasers by using Rain Flush.

Granted, the extended invincibility doesn't seem to last that long, and I can sort of understand the thought process behind it. Either way, Magma Man isn't too much of a threat so long as you stay away from the lasers and/or have Knight Crush (or Tornado Blow).

With that being said, I'm sure there's probably more..."eloquent" ways of doing this stage than how I went through it here. You really don't want to mess around in this place (especially since beating Knight Man yields a pretty good reward).

As mentioned before, going outside the standard order can help you get most of the secret items quicker. The one in Magma Man's stage is inaccessible without both Rain Flush and Spark Shock...but on the other hand, Magma Man's own weapon is required to reach hidden items in other stages. Since the secret item in this stage is close to the beginning though, it doesn't require nearly as much backtracking as some of the other ones.

As you might expect, Knight Man's stage can be pretty brutal - though in my opinion, sometimes it's for the wrong reasons entirely. My main gripe with this stage is that the only checkpoint you get (aside from the boss corridors) is at the start of the level. Also, if you happen to get a Game Over here, you don't get the chance to start this level over again. Instead, you get booted back to the beginning of the stage you found the secret entrance in.

Normally the next in line for this game's weakness chain would be Centaur Man. For now though, I've opted to take on the secret stage, which can be accessed through hidden areas in certain levels. There's a few different ways you can get to it, but the one in Toad Man's stage is probably the easiest to reach (at least, at the start of the game anyways).
